newsitem.title: USA: New Mexico debt-reform measures pass - officials.
newsitem.headline: New Mexico debt-reform measures pass - officials.

text.p: Two debt-reform initiatives on the ballot in New Mexico were narrowly approved by voters, state election officials said Thursday.

With 100 percent of precincts reporting, officials said 51 percent of voters had approved Amendment Two. The measure will provide a limited exception to the constitutional requirement that voters in a school district must approve the creation of any general obligation debt of the district.

Amendment Seven passed by a narrow margin, state election officials said. Amendment Seven authorizes counties to borrow money to acquire real estate for open space and open-space related uses and to purchase capital equipment for road and bridge construction and repair.
In addition, voters approved Amendment Four, which revises the constitutional amendment process. The amendment garnered 64 percent support with 100 percent of precincts reporting.
Voters also approved Amendment One, which will allow the state to diversify its investments. The results were delayed due to tabulation glitches, state officials said.
